item.title: Customizing the DocBook DTD
item.description: In this three-part excerpt from his new book, Norm Walsh describes how to modify the DocBook DTD and customize it for your own applications.

item.title: The Making of the DocBook DTD
item.description: The DocBook DTD grew out of the Davenport Group, and many of the people who contributed to this DTD for computer documentation have gone on to take leading roles in XML development.

item.title: Where the Web Leads Us -- Responses
item.description: Readers respond to Tim O'Reilly's perspectives on Open Source software and open standards.

item.title: XML Inter-Application Protocols
item.description: Last week, XML.com reported on a talk by Tim O'Reilly, in which he discussed the next-generation of web-centric applications. This week, Edd Dumbill presents a case why XML is already in a position to form the links between these services.

item.title: XHTML: Three Namespaces or One?
item.description: It sounds like a religious debate from the days of the Byzantine empire. Whether XHTML should have three namespaces or one has been a question that's consuming the top minds in the XML community for the last month.

item.title: Mission-critical Data
item.description: The recent loss of a spacecraft on Mars points out just how mission-critical proper data interchange is.

item.title: Where the Web Leads Us
item.description: In a talk from Linux World in Tokyo, Tim O'Reilly offers a broad perspective on the confluence of Open Source software and open standards, looking at past and future developments.

item.title: News: XOL: An XML-Based Ontology Exchange Language.
item.description: XOL is a language for ontology exchange being designed within the framework of a Molecular Biology Ontology Working Group. XOL is "designed to provide a format for exchanging ontology definitions among a set of interested parties. The ontology definitions that XOL is designed to encode include both schema information (meta-data), such as class definitions from object databases -- as well as non-schema information (ground facts) , such as object definitions from object databases. item.title: News: Automatic Graphical User Interface (AGUI) Using XML Schemas.
item.description: Roger L. Costello (MITRE Corp.) recently posted an announcement describing technology which would automatically generate GUIs from XML schemas and e-catalogues.
